page.title: 17SHEEP FARMING NEAR YANWORTH
page.content: The estate buys{Scottish mules _ {Blue Leicester crossed with Tweedsdale {or Scottish Blackface and has its own {Suffolk rams. } Present numbers are likely to rise from 1800 to 2000. One problem is raising sheep profit, c.80 /acre, nearer to cereals, c.120/acre. {Lambing}is in January and with the spare buildings available it is possible to follow the increasing tendency for indoor births _ safer and easier to monitor. But this means an increased cost for concentrates. The high stocking rate of 6 - 7 ewes/acre needs specially sown grasses _ rather than permanent pasture _ and this is resown every 4 - 5 years to maintain grass quality.More financial pressure. Autumn{fertilizer is mainly phos- phate and potassium with nitrogen more important in late spring and summer. Wet summers-1985-need less nitrogen !
